channel.title: [Idea] Project Omega - Would It Make A Difference?
channel.description:
Alright, so I had an idea the other day. What if we constructed a server browser client, that networked out into a ton of other servers? Basically it would be a full screen application (default preference), that allowed you to browse a seemingly unlimited amount of servers, and forcing the servers on this list to utilize "project omega's" (name that just sounded cool) API to send current players online, and tags and such along with it, you could browse all kinds of different private servers. Filtering by tags, players, etc. etc.. Have favorite lists, blacklists, maybe even friends that show what server's they're playing (?).. When you chose a server, the client info and cache would be downloaded by the server browser (to avoid stupidity in some client's cache downloading setup's), and then the client would start in-frame in the full screen server browser (full-screen to support server's with full-screen client's) and you could play regularly.
Thought's on this idea? Would it work? Would it be useful? Could it make a difference? That brings some other questions in like: If this were made, would it need to be moderated with quality control, or would it just be freedom to whatever developer or idiot wants to have his server on the list?

item.title: [Idea] Project Omega - Would It Make A Difference?
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

CSharp95:

I feel like the community is too small for it to be used to it’s full effect though.

Well the idea is that it would possibly bring popularity to the RSPS community, allowing smaller low-advertising budget servers to be noticed, and bring all the players into one place.

Read full topic
item.source: [Idea] Project Omega - Would It Make A Difference?

item.title: [Idea] Project Omega - Would It Make A Difference?
item.dc:creator: @CSharp95 CSharp95
item.description:
@CSharp95 wrote:

Whether or not it works depends on the people developing it.
If it will be useful, I honestly can’t say.

I enjoy doing some programming from time to time, and all of the programs I make are almost always based around making it as seamless and simple for even the most basic user to understand. So, something like this could actually be quite handy to a lot of people.

I feel like the community is too small for it to be used to it’s full effect though.

Read full topic
item.source: [Idea] Project Omega - Would It Make A Difference?

item.title: [Idea] Project Omega - Would It Make A Difference?
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

sinisoul:

Before you jump into this think about your target consumer group. It’s small. And the level at which this would be useable isn’t there.

The idea is that anybody would be able to use it essentially, like the server browser feature in source games.

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:3, topic:551205”]I don’t see how you would accomplish half of what you listed…

You say “When you chose a server, the client info and cache would be downloaded by the server browser (to avoid stupidity in some client’s cache downloading setup’s)”

How are you going to manage that? Are you gonna make an interface for server owners to update the cache links and versions? How are you going to verify that the cache is working and good? What if the link 404’s? what if the user zipped their data incorrectly?

Your best solution would be to do what MoparScape used to do…
Have 1 client. Make it work for as many servers as possible. Allow the port and ip to be changed. The rest is server sided.[/quote]

How are you going to manage that?
In theory, you would have a wrapper or launcher type thing where each individual client code base would be downloaded and ran inside the program itself, somehow.

Are you gonna make an interface for server owners to update the cache links and versions?
That would be the idea.

How are you going to verify that the cache is working and good?/What if the link 404’s?/what if the user zipped their data incorrectly?
Of course that would all be handled by the server browser itself, as any good program should catch all possible user mistakes.

Zymus:

Also, (something that I’ve run into on my own project), what if the developer of the client has malicious code in it? And part of downloading the cache was downloading their malicious files to the user’s computer?

That’s where my point about quality control comes in at the bottom there.

Also, for the record, I’m not talking about developing this myself or with anybody else, merely just an idea I wanted to throw out there and discuss. Thanks for the feedback.

Read full topic
item.source: [Idea] Project Omega - Would It Make A Difference?

item.title: [Idea] Project Omega - Would It Make A Difference?
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus

You say “When you chose a server, the client info and cache would be downloaded by the server browser (to avoid stupidity in some client’s cache downloading setup’s)”

How are you going to manage that? Are you gonna make an interface for server owners to update the cache links and versions? How are you going to verify that the cache is working and good? What if the link 404’s? what if the user zipped their data incorrectly?

Your best solution would be to do what MoparScape used to do…
Have 1 client. Make it work for as many servers as possible. Allow the port and ip to be changed. The rest is server sided.[/quote]

Also, (something that I’ve run into on my own project), what if the developer of the client has malicious code in it? And part of downloading the cache was downloading their malicious files to the user’s computer?
